So I'm having the most difficult time making this docking node attach to a rover I'm trying to add to this plane. I wanted it to work with the Mk2 Clamp o tron (even though ideally I wanted a Jr. sized docking node), but then was willing to settle for anything that worked. Nothing does! I don't know what I'm doing wrong; I haven't had trouble with docking node attachments before. Hopefully this picture explains my woes, I don't really know how else to explain what is going wrong. I just can't seem to get the nodes to want to attach. Holding down alt makes the problem 'worse' in that it won't even be anywhere near where it should be attached. When I attach it as it looks in the picture, it's actually inside the other port and undocking in game does nothing. I've tried offsetting it so they are very close but not technically touching, but they still act like they are inside each other, and it wont let go of the rover. The heck is wrong?

I'm trying to understand what you're doing, here.  The screenshot is kinda hard to understand.  Is it the case that you have a docking port that's already mounted on the plane, and you have a rover that already has a docking port mounted to it, and you're trying somehow to connect the rover to the plane?  Something else?

If that's the case, a couple of things:

  • First, I don't think it's actually possible to connect anything to any of the "coverable" docking ports (inline, Mk2, or shielded) in the VAB.  Only the "simple" ports are attachable this way.  (I don't know this from firsthand experience, since I basically never use any of the coverable ones, but I seem to recall reading about this in the forum).
  • Any time you try to attach a subassembly, you can only do it via the subassembly's root part.  So if, for example, the subassembly is a rover with a docking port, and you want to attach it via the docking port, then the subassembly has to be saved with the docking port as root.

Yes, you understood correctly. I have a rover subassembly, with a plane that has a docking port. I finally maneuvered a docking port on the plane and got it attached, but I wanted to use the Mk2, and it fails to work. It sounds like the error is something to do with the subassembly? How do I save a subassembly if it has a root part? I thought specifically assemblies could not be saved if they had a root part.

Right, because I believe that the Mk2 docking port won't allow connecting anything to it in the VAB or SPH.  There's no particular reason why it shouldn't, it just doesn't.  Missing feature, I suppose.

5 minutes ago, KocLobster said:

It sounds like the error is something to do with the subassembly? How do I save a subassembly if it has a root part? I thought specifically assemblies could not be saved if they had a root part.

Everything has a root part. It's how KSP works.  Everything in KSP is a tree: whenever you have parts that are connected, every part has exactly one parent part... except for the one, single part that has no parent, and that part is the root part.  It's simply not physically possible to have a set of connected parts without one of them being the root.

So your subassembly will have a root part.  The catch is that the root part is the only one that can attach to anything when you load the subassembly.  So if, for example, the root part of your rover is something buried in the middle of it with other parts all around, then what you have there is an unattachable rover.  Fortunately, it's fixable-- just use the re-rooting tool to move the root to the docking port before saving the rover as a subassembly, then it'll be attachable via the docking port.

It seems pretty central to the whole idea of the part... What is it that causes me to be unable to sometimes save sub assemblies then? I thought it was the root feature, but I guess it has to do with command pods?

I assume it wasn't implemented because making it work was somehow hard, based on the animated behavior.  Being able to dock is central to the idea of the part.  Being able to connect it in the SPH isn't.  A nice-to-have, yes, but not necessarily the primary reason for it to be there.

As for why the game isn't letting you save the subassembly:  I assume it's because you haven't made the craft with an attachable root.  Unless you've made an assembly that has an exposed connection node, it would be completely unattachable.  So I assume it has to do with the game not wanting to let you save a subassembly that you couldn't use for anything.

I have to admit that I'm a bit fuzzy in this area, though, since I only very rarely use subassemblies.

The issue with subassemblies is that it cannot contain the root of the main craft. The part you want it to connect by is the root of the subassembly, in that it must be the parent of all the attached parts, but this part itself must be detached from the craft root in order to be saved. Your issue with command pods is likely that the command pod was the first part placed upon starting a new craft, and was thus the root by default. What you will want to do is attach something like a girder to your desired parent part, use the Root Gadget on *that*, and detach the desired parent from the new root to be able save it as a subassembly with that open node.
I think I understand how it works now, thanks guys
